title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Nowhere had I been wise I should at once have gone down the last-named tothe upper waters of Tweed near the village of Tweedsmuir, whence I mighthave come without danger to the wilder hills and the Cor Waterhiding-place.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Far to the right, where the Talla joinsthe Tweed, we could mark the few lights of the little village ofTweedsmuir.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: A' the folk o' Brochtoun and Tweedsmuir,and awa' ower by Clyde Water ken that there's no his match for rinnin'and speelin' and shootin' wi' the musket; I'll find my way oot o' a holewhen a' body else 'ill bide in't.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Now Tweed, unlike all other rivers of my knowledge, rises terribly atthe first rain and travels slowly, so that Tweedsmuir may be under fivefeet of water and Peebles high and dry.

title: Rab and His Friends and Other Papers
author: Brown, John
snippet: His master, a brown, handsome, big young shepherd from Tweedsmuir, would have liked to have knocked down any man, would "drink up Esil, or eat a crocodile," for that part, if he had a chance: it was no use kicking the little dog; that would only make him hold the closer.

title: Noctes ambrosianae,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: I dinna understaun  your aye gaun up to the Cruick-Inn in Tweedsmuir.

title: Noctes Ambrosianæ.
author: Wilson, John
snippet: I dinna understaun'  your aye gaun up to the Cruick-Inn in Tweedsmuir.

title: The works of Professor Wilson of the University of Edinburgh,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: A few gulps of Tweedsmuir air have made us quite a young elderly gentleman.

title: The works of Professor Wilson of the University of Edinburgh,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: You must know that we are on the way to the Crook Inn in Tweedsmuir.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The Hartfell group of mountains is the highest in the south of Scotland, and the heights of the principal summits are as follows  : — Hartfell, 2G41 feet above the level of the sea ; Whitecorn  (looking down on Loch Skene), 2685 ; Broadlaw (in Peeblesshire, and Tweedsmuir parish), 2741 ; Ettrick Pen, 2256; Saddleback and Lochcraig, not ascertained.

title: Tweed and Don; or, Recollections and reflections of an angler for the last fifty years ...
author: Locke, James.
snippet: To our piscatory  friends in the South, say at Richmond or Maidenhead, this is the great day of all the week for their sport of angling ! but here we have no such custom; and, I will venture to inform them, that from Tweedsmuir to Tweedmouth, not a line for salmon, salar, trout, or par, is cast on its waters, so well is the Sunday kept on Tweedside  ! ! But it may be said by some of our Southern brethren of the angle, What are you to do when in the country, on this day, if you do not fish, read ? No, not entirely so.

title: Tweed and Don; or, Recollections and reflections of an angler for the last fifty years ...
author: Locke, James.
snippet: have not only beautiful scenery but good fishing,  and it rejoiceth me to say, that you may fish the whole river, from Berwick to Tweedsmuir, for trout, without being challenged by any one.

title: The world's best essays, from the earliest period to the present time;
author: Brewer, David J.
snippet: His master, a brown, handsome, big young shepherd from Tweedsmuir,  would have liked to have knocked down any man, would "drink up Esil, or eat a crocodile," for that part, if he had a chance: it was no use kicking the little dog; that would only make him hold the closer.
